name: Standing Overhead Dummbell Press
notes: This is a warmup exercise. Use light weights (5, 10, 15lbs), and focus on form, using one arm at a time
Dumbbells should come down to your ears, with your elbows pointed down -- all the way to bringing your bicep to your ear. Focus on form
Bring the dumbbells down, breath in. Push up, breath out. It may be helpful to cross your opposite arm against your chest

name: Dumbbell Front Raise
notes: This is a warmup exercise. Use light weights (5, 10, 15lbs), and focus on form, using one arm at a time
Stand with your feed shoulder-width apart, toes pointed forward
Do not swing the dumbbell back and forth -- the dumbbell should come to a complete stop on both the upswing and downswing
Exhale when you push the dumbbell forward and up -- breath in bringing it down. Try and bring it down slowly

name: Dumbbell Lateral Raise
notes: This is a warmup exercise. Use light weights (5, 10, 15lbs), and focus on form, using one arm at a time
Stand with your feed shoulder-width apart, toes pointed forward
Do not swing the dumbbell back and forth -- the dumbbell should come to a complete stop on both the upswing and downswing
Exhale when you push the dumbbell to the side and up -- breath in bringing it down. Try and bring it down slowly

name: Dumbbell Lunge
notes: Do the listed number of reps per-leg
This is a warmup exercise. Use light weights (5, 10, 15lbs), and focus on form, using one arm at a time
Keep the dumbbells to your side, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing forward
Take a long step and bend with your rear knee -- both your front and rear knees should form a 90-degree (right) angle
When pushing up, focus on using the mid-back of your feet to push yourself up
Inhale while bending, and exhale when standing

name: Dumbbell/Kettlebell Sumo Squat
notes: Hold the weight slightly below chest level
Legs should be a little wider than shoulder width, pointed slightly outward
When pushing up, focus on using the mid-back of your feet to push yourself up. You shouldn't fall, but if you do, try to fall backwards
Inhale while bending, and exhale when pushing up to stand

name: Bodyweight Squat
notes: A kind of warm-down exercise to work on no-weight stability, to practice your own natural balance
Legs should be a little wider than shoulder width, pointed slightly outward
When pushing up, focus on using the mid-back of your feet to push yourself up. You shouldn't fall, but if you do, try to fall backwards
Inhale while bending, and exhale when pushing up to stand

name: Machine Seated Calf Raise
notes: You will do 7 reps apiece - one with a neutral stance (toes pointed up, pressing middle of foot), one with a wide-stance (toes pointed out, pressing with inner foot), and one with a narrow-stance (toes pointed in, pressing with outer foot)
For the wide-stance, you almost want to push with your big toe, which should be the central point of force. For the narrow-stance, push with your pinky toes
Feet and legs should be shoulder-width
Inhale while bending, and exhale when pushing up

name: Seated Leg Curl
notes: Do not use your back to assist the curl. Your back should remain straight up
Legs should be shoulder-width, and the curl pad should come to a rest at the top of your heels (right against your shoe/skin)
Inhale while curling, exhale when straightening your legs

name: Standing Figure 4
notes: Place your foot [square] on the table, and your other leg shoulder-width next to it (see image). The leg on the flor should have toes pointed forward
Breath in deep with your back straight, and bend AT THE HIP. Do not look downwards -- look up or straight ahead
Remember to breath in as you begin, and breath out as you push your stretch further. Do not attempt to go as hard as you can on your first attempt - warm up the stretch

name: Standing Hamstring Stretch
notes: Place your heel on the box, toe pointed up. Place your other foot toe-facing-forward, both feet should be about shoulder-width apart

Breath in deep with your back straight, and bend AT THE HIP, with your arms and fingers extended straight up. Bend as far as comfortable can, resting your fingertops on the tips of your feet if possible, or your legs if not
Remember to breath in as you begin, and breath out as you push your stretch further. Do not attempt to go as hard as you can on your first attempt - warm up the stretch

name: Outer-Calf Wall Stretch
notes: Place your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointed forward, with one leg far behind the other. The front leg should be a few inches away from the wall

Place your hands flat against the wall for support. You will achieve the stretch from this exercise by bending your back leg further and further down at the heel (remember to keep the back of your foot against the ground!)
Remember to breath in as you begin, and breath out as you push your stretch further. Do not attempt to go as hard as you can on your first attempt - warm up the stretch

name: Inner-Calf Wall Stretch
notes: Place your feet shoulder-width apart. The front foot will have your heel on the ground, and the front of your foot against the wall. Your foot should be a direct 45-degree angle.
Place your hands flat against the wall for support. You will achieve the stretch from this exercise by bending your front knee forward, which will push your calf further and further into the stretch
Take this stretch slowly! It is easy to push it too far
Remember to breath in as you begin, and breath out as you push your stretch further. Do not attempt to go as hard as you can on your first attempt - warm up the stretch

name: Quadriceps Wall Stretch
notes: Facing away from a wall, place your knee at the corner of the wall/floor, with your leg parallel to the wall. Place your other leg forward and in front of you, similar to a lunghe - it should form a right-angle.
Using this leg as support, push yourself up. The ideal position is to be able to lay your back against your leg on the wall
Take this stretch slowly! It is easy to push it too far
Remember to breath in as you begin, and breath out as you push your stretch further. Do not attempt to go as hard as you can on your first attempt - warm up the stretch
